clean_story:
Tiny worlds. Built by erosion.


A grain of sand is just a broken rock—ground down by wind, water, or ice until it’s small enough to fit in your palm.
Most sand starts as quartz, a hard mineral that resists weathering, like the last stubborn piece of candy in a crushed bag.
But sand isn’t just quartz.
Beaches near volcanoes hold black grains of basalt.
Tropical shores glitter with crushed coral and shell fragments, sharp-edged like tiny broken plates.
Desert sands are rounder—tumbled for thousands of years, like stones in a giant’s pocket.
Some grains even carry secrets: tiny fossils, gold flakes, or bits of space dust older than Earth itself.
Next time you hold sand, you’re holding mountains, oceans, and time—all reduced to specks.

Glassmaking.
How rivers carve canyons.
Why some beaches sing when you walk on them.
